subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] lexical set: my set for general American English
msgSnippet: ... To address your specific points: 1) I think that Ah is clearly superior to Ox for people who merge PALM + THOUGHT; the change is in fact one where the
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> John and Anthony, here is a concrete chart that I think would work for
> Americans. It is just a proposal, but I thought something concrete would
> help the debate rather than something abstract.

To address your specific points:

1) I think that Ah is clearly superior to Ox for people who merge PALM
+ THOUGHT; the change is in fact one where the vowel of PALM has been
adopted in the THOUGHT words too. Someone who distinguishes "palm" from
"thought" will, I think be extremely confused to see "palm" written with
Ox; it would suggest "Pom" (Australian slang for Brits). Whereas "thaht"
can be written off as a "bloody Americanism".

2) Some Americans resolve NEAR = SQUARE in favor of NEAR (they say
"squeer"), whereas others resolve it in favor of SQUARE (they say "nare").
Both are minority viewpoints: the majority keep the distinction.
This is going to be tricky.

3) Nobody fully merges KIT and DRESS; the neutralization in Southern
American (and some forms of Californian) occurs before /n/ and /m/ only.
I don't have a good plan for what to do about this.

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
One time I called in to the central system and started working on a big
thick 'sed' and 'awk' heavy duty data bashing script. One of the geologists
came by, looked over my shoulder and said 'Oh, that happens to me too.
Try hanging up and phoning in again.' --Beverly Erlebacher
